titleNullable: AAU Sewer Defect Point Cloud Dataset
subtitleNullable: Sewer defect classification of point clouds using real and synthetic data
descriptionNullable:
###Multi-class Classification of 3D Sewer Defects

The sewerage infrastructure is of utmost importance for modern society. Million kilometers of sewer pipes extend beyond our feet, keep wastewater away from the streets, leading to better public health and environment. However, due to the extend of the infrastructure sewer pipes are inspected with several year gaps. This can lead to premature replacement of the pipes to avoid pipe failures.

Traditionally 2D image data is used for sewer inspections, when looking for defects. However, in recent years the 3D sensor technologies have started maturing, opening the possibility of using 3D sensor data for defect classification in sewer pipes.

This is the ***first*** publicly available dataset of 3D data of sewer pipes and defects. The majority of the dataset consists of synthetic data, while the point clouds of real pipes were recorded recorded in a laboratory environment at Aalborg University, Denmark. 

A set of dry plastic pipes were used, with defects introduced by displacing the pipes, placing rubber rings or bricks inside the pipes. The data was obtained using a Pico Flexx Time-of-Flight sensor.



### Content and Annotations
The two sub-datasets were obtained in the following way. Each point cloud is annotated with one of the four possible classes
- Normal
- Displacement
- Brick
- Rubber Ring

The synthetic dataset was obtained by simulating a Pico Flexx ToF sensor in a virtual environment using a modified approach based on [Henriksen et al.](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-030-58468-9_26) which use Structured Domain Randomization. The synthetic generator can be found at out [bitbucket codebase](https://bitbucket.org/aauvap/sewer3dclassification)

The real point cloud dataset was obtained using a Pico Flexx sensor to record dry plastic pipes in laboratory settings. The different defects were introduced by placing rubber ring segments, bricks, and displacing the pipes.

The data provided is the subsampled version used for the results in the paper.

Code and scripts used for analysis of the data  and training the PointNet/DGCNN networks can be found at our [bitbucket](https://bitbucket.org/aauvap/sewer3dclassification) (bitbucket.org/aauvap/sewer3dclassification)  .
